'Keeping up to the windward of the same', and soon as commences:  follow up immediately in it's wake.  by so doing, you are out of danger from the fire that is coming down upon you, as it is checked in it's course as soon as it reaches the point where you set fire. -- This is but one, among the many, sad, and fearful scenes, we have experienced on this trip -- not sufferers bodily, however! from all, , we have witnessed -- but enough  -- to satisfy us now, 'if not before we started on this journey.'  That it was, one -- and has been, one, in which one is in constant danger from beginning to end, day & night. -- Then again -- we have had the pleasure of beholding the most splendid scenery, on this, continent, at least; if not, in the known world. -- nor has this been all, Such unaccountable curiosities too.  -- That one could hardly believe his own eyes -- ears -- or hands, till forced to -- or compelled to, from his own personal experiences, observation, &c - and too innumerable to be mentioned at this time, were I able to. -- would just mention here now, having witnessed it today, in our travels most distinctly, than before, as near, as the most deceptive -- The Mirage here in this Valley -- one would almost take his oath, That he saw a village -- fields,  -- forests -- persons - or cattle, some times one, -- some times another,

Sunday Sept. 16th, -- Pleasant, we left camp at 7 Am -- were obliged to stop several times during the day for our animals to rest, / hard work for some of them to get along. / however! we arrived safe at the Sacramento River, about 3 Pm.  we were all of us, much pleased This point, in our travels, as we have had a long, and tedious journey of it. -- and we find ourselves, pretty well worn out, -- as much as our animals. -- we camped on the North Fork of the American River, some 3 miles from the City, of Sacramento, and north from the city -- we could see the white cloth houses,  as we came along today we saw the Prairies on fire in the distance.  could see them,  that was anywheres near, scatter for their lives.  It raged with great fury, and swept over the plains with lightning speed, almost,  fortunately for us, as we were, some little distance from where it commenced, and to the windwards of it, -- we past on, and left it burning. --  These fires, make sad work some times -- especially for such, as are to the leeward of Them, as it travels with such speed, almost impossible to escape.  Many a poor fellow has lost his life bt them, / when in this situation. // seeing one of these fires coming down upon you with such force -- it is best to set fire to the grass.  Where

Tuesday Sept 18th. -- The Dr returned to camp early this morning.  lost his way last Eve so spent the night in another camp somewhere, he has gone to town again today -- I have not been away from camp since we arrived here, -- I expect to go to The City tomorrow however! -- two of our mules, while down at the stream drinking got missing, one of them we got out.  The other died There. -- Old Tom is the one we saved, -- Mike died, he is one we picked up some days since, -- neither would have been Lost, had they any strength left, to have helped themselves in the least.  As it was, they were so weak, they couldnot help themselves much -- and we have hard work to save one,  even. -- Wednesday, Sept 19th. -- Pleasant.  Geo & I went to the City this Am. Saw Frank Bush and Mr Smith.  "LH's intended" gave them letters handed me in Boston for them -- we dined with Mr Smith in his tent, where he kept a provision stand, or store -- also saw several other I knew among them Thos Seward and Baxter Cass of So Boston, -- we returned to camp again about 4 Pm. --

in the distance before us.   but never were we able to see them.  / as they appeared to us, / Through the Mirage -- as there was nothing of the kind here to be seen -- as our journeying on, and on, moved. -- however! it was beautiful to look at. -- Never have we seen it so splendid before in our travels. -- as have said before, we are all most happy in reaching the plain -- and feel that we have now reached our journeys end.  or nearly so.  as the rest, to San Francisco, we expect to go by vessel &c -- no more Mule travel for us, say we for the present. -- distance traveled today, 25 miles. --  Monday Sept 17th. -- Pleasant, we find Mr Holcomb Ingalsby -- Chapman -- & Smith, encamped here -- these are the ones that left us at Pearl River, about six weeks since. -- Geo and the Dr. concluded to go to Town.  So they took a bath and fixed up after dinner.  They started for Sacramento -- and I remained in camp here alone. -- Geo returned about 9 Pm. alone, having lost the Dr -- Somewhere on the way -- He told me he saw Frank Bush, and several others he knows, and was pleased with his visit,

Friday Sept 21st. -- Pleasant.  Geo not any better this morning. -- had an offer for our Mules this Am. from Mr Chapman, but not enough as we thought.  So would not sell.  did not see his Wolfship, last night. --  Saturday Sept 22nd. -- Pleasant.  Geo not so well this morning.  Moved our camp for grass, about a mile back, from where we were, -- are in hopes to get out of this place soon, as we think it unhealthy here, so low & damp. -- Sunday Sept 23rd. -- Pleasant.  Geo has been very sick last nigh -- he woke us up in the night in great distress -- we were very much alarmed about him -- The Dr after some time relieved him some, but we were with him all night -- as Geo is so sick, we thought it best to get away from This plain, soon as possible, -- as the Dr does not think Geo will be any better so long as we remain here "Camping out."  So after breakfast I started off for the City, in order to sell our mules if possible and get away from this place, as soon as Geo could be moved -- I came acrost the

Thursday Sept 20th. -- Pleasant.  I went to the City again this morning, and called on Mrs Woodland, the Lady we became acquainted with on board of the Steamer on the Mo River -- saw 2 or 3 Boston vessels Laying here side of the river.  Among Them the Bark Elvira, an old trap, that left Boston. -- found it very warm in Town -- and has been for several days, am told thermomator has been 110 & 115 in the shade for one or two nights.  The prairie wolves, have been in camp. and stoled things from our camp kettle, that stood within 20 feet of us -- we at first, thought it must be some person that came in and stole our provisions &c and though we would keep watch &c -- when -- lo & behold along comes thief, in the shape of a Wolf.  if he came -- byandby he came & wake me by rattling the kettle &c, I drew my gun up, and in the act of raising the hammer he heard me -- and off he went, without getting a shot at him. -- Geo has been quite sick for a day or two with Dysentery. --

the Schnr Pomento, Captn Patterson, for San Francisco -- as he does not expect to sail till tomorrow, we are to stop on board till he does sail.  passage to San Francisco 'in Cabin' $30 -- Thursday Sept 27th. -- Pleasant.  Saw Mr Baugh, of Lowell, the Am.  he, was rather homesick -- we left Sacramento about 2 Pm with some 25 or 30 passengers all bound to San Francisco - - most of them are from the mines -- and the most of them Sick too -- one poor fellow laying on his back in the hold, not able to move, so sick.  Geo is better today, but very weak tho. -- Friday Sept 28th. -- Pleasant.  we lay aground most of the night, got ashore by luffing, to let another vessel pass us, that was bound up -- we went so far, nor time -- nor room, to come about, and her bows were run in among the bushes, so could step ashore -- we laid there till about 4 Oclock, This Am before could get off again. -- Geo some better today -- the poor fellow in the hold, about the same. --

Holcomb & Ingaldsby, and sold them all to them, my horse, and all. -- Then returned to camp -- found Geo about the same as when I left.  --  Monday Sept 24th. -- Pleasant.  Geo is more comfortable this morning. -- Mr Holcomb came and took all of our animals away the Am.  So we now are somewhat relieved, as we have not them to look after now -- and we intend to leave here for San Francisco, as soon as Geo is able to be moved. -- Tuesdau, Sept 25th. -- Pleasant.  Geo is some better this morning -- the Dr has gone to the City to see about engaging passage for us to San Francisco -- he returned saying a vessel sails tomorrow Am -- so we are to leave here tomorrow if possible. -- Wednesday, Sept 26th. -- Pleasant.  Geo is better this morning, so we think it best to leave here. --So chartered a team, have our things put on board and started for Sacramento -- where we engaged passage on board of

Put up at the Franklin House, run by a Mr Ford from N York -- after had some breakfast.  Started for the Post Office here I found letters from home, and most happy was I to receive them.  The more so, as from them.  Learnt all were well at home &c -- This the first have heard from them since I left St. Louis Mo, also learnt from on of Geos letters "brother Georges". that Saml Greene, was here, 'or expected here.'  in looking round to find out if he had arrived &c I came acrost him as was coming out of the Harbor Master's Office, where I went, to see if the vessel had arrived he 'was expected,  -- was most happy to meet eachother so far from home -- I went to his office a few moments, and then returned to house. -- The evening was very cold & damp, so did not go out again after returning &c. -- This, like most of the houses here, except 5 or 6 that were built before the Gold discovery, are built by driving stakes in the ground, then tacking white cotton cloth around forming the sides.  The roof, is also built of the same material, common, Cotton Cloth. -- our dining room however! as well as the bar room, are created with boards -- the sleeping apartments, are of cloth, as before stated, with berths arranged around the sides, three or four tier high. --

Saturday Sept 29th. -- Pleasant.  Geo is improving. -- we were towed though what is called the Slough, by a small Steam Boat This Pm -- soon after she left us, we got aground, and here we laid hard & fast at times we retired &c  Sunday Sept 30th. -- Pleasant.  we lay aground all night got under way again about daylight. -- past New York about 3 Pm -- and arrived at Benecia about 4, where we stoped for a few moments -- here, at this place, there are several US vessels -- the Naval Stores, are also there -- and from this place the US Vessels fit out &c -- There are also several Merchantmen laying here, all Laid up. -- Soon after leaving this place, the wind died away, and we came to anchor about dark, some 20 or 25 miles from San Francisco. -- Monday Oct 1st. -- Pleasant.  Geo much better -- we arrived at San Francisco about daylight.  Landed about 2 Am -- and

put up at the Franklin House, kept by a Mr Ford from N York -- after had some breakfast, started for the Post Office -- there I found letters from home, and most happy was I, to receive them.  The more so, as from them, Learnt that all were well at home &c -- This is the first have heard from home, since I left St. Louis Mo.   also learnt from one of Geos letters "brother Georges", that Saml Greene was here, 'or expected here,' in looking round to find out if he had arrived &c I came acrost him as was coming out of the Harbor Master's Office, where I went to see if the vessel had arrived he 'was expected -- was most happy to meet eachother so far from home -- I went to his office a few moments and then returned to house --  The Evening was very cold and damp, so did not go out again after returning &c.  This, like most of the houses here 'except 5 or 6 that were built before the Gold discovery.' are built by driving stakes in the ground, then tacking white cotton cloth around, forming the sides.  The roof, is also built of the same material, common Cotton Cloth. -- our dining room however! as well as the bar room, are covered with boards -- the sleeping apartments, are of Cloth, as before stated.  With berths arranged around the Sides, three or four tier high. --

Saturday Sept 29th. -- Pleasant.  Geo is improving. -- we were towed through what is called The Slough, by  a small Steam Boat this Pm.  soon after she left us we got aground, and here we laid hard & fast, at time we retired &c.  Sunday Sept 30th. -- Pleasant.  We lay aground all night got under way again about daylight. -- Past New York about 3 Pm - and arrived at Benecia about 4, where we stopsd a few moments -- here, at this place, there are several U S Vessels -- the Naval Stores, are also here -- and from this place, the U S Vessels fit out &c -- There are also several Merchantmen laying here, all laid up. -- Soon after leaving this place, the wind died away, and we came to anchor about dark, some 20 or 25 miles from San Francisco. -- Monday Oct 1st. -- Pleasant.  Geo much better -- we arrived at San Francisco about daylight, landed about 8 Am -- and

have arrived here by vessels, appear to affected the worst. -- for nearly a month, I have been very lame in my ankles, and feet, almost impossible for me to get about, at times, at first.  Thought was Rheumatism, but have come to the conclusion, that it must be the Scurvy.  They are very painful, and it appears to me to be, in the bone of my ankles and feet, -- as I touch my heels to the ground, to the ground, it is terrible, as if Thousands of red-hot needles, were run into my heels -- I have been obliged to walk on my toes, most of the time.  Have bathed them in linaments the Dr. prepared for me. -- but did not help them in the least, that I could see. -- Some milder this Evening. -- Thursday Oct 4th. -- Pleasant.  Geo has gone into Messers Osborn & Brannons Store as Salesman.  My diarrhoea, and Scurvy, about the same, not well enough to go round much, can hobble round a little Tho  Friday Oct 5th. -- Pleasant -- am about the same as yesterday.  This place is all alive with

Tuesday Oct 2nd. -- Pleasant.  We found our sleeping apartments, quite airy last night.  we could lay in our berths and count the stars, through the cloth roof over our heads. -- The will answer so long as it is pleasant, but in case of rain, if must be awfull here.  We hope for better quarters then. -- I went to work and put Some berths up in Saml Green's counting room, for him.  he has hired a Room in the second story, of a new wooden building, just erected here on Montgomery Street.  Size, about 10 Ft, by 12, his room.  Entrance, on the outside, So are not obliged to go through the building below at all. -- The building is situated on high land, overlooking the Whole City. -- Wednesday, Oct 3rd. -- Pleasant.  Quite cold & damp last night, didnot suffer Tho with the cold -- When on board , Each person has to find his own bedding. -- I finished the berths for Saml Greene today. -- Since our arrival here, we have all been troubled with a Diarrhoea, and we find all others are troubled in the same way.  Some - are very sick with it, dangerously.  The change of diet, the cause, no doubt.  Those that

Monday Oct 8th 1849. -- Foggy and cold.  Saml Greene has offered me lodgings at his room, in one of the births I put up for him &c. -- I accepted his kind offer and moved my things up there -- there is three of us here now.  Mr Greene -- Cohen & Myself. -- am happy to think have so fine accommodations, better, then can be found any where else in this place -- except some private house, and an old residence ar unclear even, I think. -- diarrhoea better, Scurvy about the same. --

excitement, the vessels arriving evry day with passengers, bound for the diggings  not one -- that is willing to stop short of the mines -- Hundreds are laving for them day by -- Sunday Oct 7th. -- Cloudy all day, with fog.  I attended Church in the Am, with Saml Greene, and his friend Cohen -- The audience was composed of a most singular set, with but one or two Ladies.  The rest are men, and in as many colors and styles of dress, as you could possibly imagine, half of the audience in Their Red & Blue, Shirt Sleeves, "woolen," with now & then, a white one -- This the only Protestant Church here at present, -- and Orthodox.  Rev Mr Wheeler, as Pastor of Same. --

1851  From a Journal of a Voyage from San Francisco, Cala to New York -- on board the Steamer North America, Capt Blesten -- We are to go by the way of San Juan -- or the Nicaragua Route, so called  That is -- we are to cross here providing there is a Steamer ready to receive us on the Atlantic Side at San-Juan-de-Norte, or Greytown. -- This is a new route, and this, is but the second boat, that has, taken 'or is about to take' passengers for this route.  Through, to New York -- and, as there is some doubt, of a steamer being ready for us at Greytown, The company agrees to take us by way of Panama, (some two days sail further down on this side) -- providing, a boat is not ready for us at Greytown &c  Thought best to go this route as we will have but ten miles, of land travel in crossing at this point -- as "They say--" can make the passage to New York in some two or three days less time, than by Panama &c --  So we are to start tomorrow for home -- via Nicaragua Route. --

Wednesday, Oct 15th. -- Pleasant, but cool.  We find ourselves in the same place as when we retired last evening -- Engineer not returned at Sunrise -- I C Woods came on board with papers for me from Adams & Co office -- The mail Steamer Cala past us about 6 1/2 Am, bound out for the States, via Panama  Our Engineer returning about 10 Am -- and we were soon under way again at 25 minutes past 10, heading for the Gate -- soon pass it and were clear and safe from land.  Some fog this morning --  Have a fine days run, are in hopes of passing the Cala before many days -- cannot see her this Pm. -- Thursday Oct 16th. -- A Splendid Morning, calm -- had a good nights run -- we are going along finely This morning -- at 12 n were in Lat 35-56. A -- Lon 120-40 . W -- distance from San Francisco 273 miles. -- Friday, Oct 17th. -- Pleasant.  Small Island of Guadeloupe in Sight, on Starboard bow at 12 n -- at same time in Lat 30-12. A -- Long 110-25 w -- distance last 24 hours -- 260. mils. --

Tuesday, Oct 14th, 1851. --  I left San Francisco this Pm in company with Mr Lawson T Adams. /my late partner in business here./  for home --  we left our friends Messers E.G. & O's place at 1/2 past 2 Oclock Pm -- for the Steamer.  we stopped at Adams & Co Express office on our way -- to receive his express bag, as I was to be his messenger through &c  received the Same, and went on board about 4 Pm -- Several of our friends accompanied us on board to see us off &c .  after biding our friends farewell / Geo O. being the last to leave the Ship -- as She have cast all off, and swung round so that was obliged to jump a long distance, and was caught by those on the wharf safe./ we were under way 20 minutes before 6 PM -- on board of the Steamer North America, Capt Blethen.  we run down about a mile and came to anchor, as we were short of hands on board, and, it was very foggy too. -- found we were like to remain here all night, so we turned in about 9, as wel wished to get up early to see the harbour &c as we past out -- our Engineer went ashore soon as we anchored, to see if he could find more hands for the Ship &c

Tuesday Oct, 21st. -- Cloudy all day, no observation today -- heavy sea on, and but light head wind -- Showers through the day.  Capt had awning rigd to catch the water, in case we should run short of same -- have to amuse ourselves as best we can today, as have said, we have same pleasant company on board -- and some not so pleasant -- some that make all around them feel unpleasant, great brags & know nothings.  Distance last 24 hours to 12 n -- about 250 miles. -- Wednesday, Oct 22nd. -- Pleasant morning -- last night have heavy showers, with wind, and a very heave sea -- bad sea on this morning too.  got out of it about noon Tho at 12 n -- no Lat 17-42 North -- Long 102-56 West -- distance last 24 hours -- 156 miles -- and 185 miles to Acapulco.  pleasant this Pm I amuse myself by seeing the Missourians Pikes, playing Euchre &c  Thursday, Oct 23rd. -- Pleasant, but very warm. past Acapulco about 6 Am  could not see the place hid by the Hills, from view as vessels pass up

Saturday Oct 18th. -- Pleasant.  Has been growing warm for a day or two.  Head wind today -- at 12 N -- in Lat 26-47 North -- Long 115-05 -- West.  distance traveled Las 24 hours 268. miles. -- we have some 3 or 400 passengers on board many of them German Jews, poor company for us.  We have however! some pleasant company on board.  The Capt is very pleasant, has his wife on board with him.  This is his first trip down.  He arrived but a few days before we left, with this boat, from New York. -- Sunday, Oct 19th. -- A Splendid day.  quite warm, with light winds from The South -- our course has been nearly SE, ever since we Left San Francisco -- at 12 N in Lat. 23-40 N Long 111-40 West.  distance Last 24 hours, 282 miles. -- Monday, Oct 20th. -- Pleasant and very warm.  Light wind ahead.  at 12 N. in Lat 20-54 N, Long 108-24. West.  distance last 24 hours 270 miles -- many of our passengers amusing themselves playing cards -- Especially those in forward Cabin, Western Men mostly --

in crossing here. /Should the wind continue ahead shall be longer/.  at 12 n in Lat 14-67 North, Long 95-15 West -- distance last 24. hours 200 miles. --  Sail in sight. -- the  propeller, Monumental City, bound up.  She is some 12 to 15 miles off on our Larbord in Shore. -- not so comfortable moving about Ship today, so rough,  Some, are quite Sea sick -- cloudy all day -- Some fine rain this Am -- and cooler  . . . --  Saturday, Oct 25th. -- A Splendid Morning.  past a Bark about Sun rise, bound down.  She was some 8 or 10 miles off Tho  also saw The Smoke of a Steamer a Long distance off.  could not see her hull.  warm again today -- at 12 N in Lat 13-06. North, Long. 91-10. West.  Distance the last 24 hours, 260 miles. -- at 5 Oclock P M, are within 325 miles of San-Juan-del-Sur. -- where we expect to land -- if a Steamer is ready for us on the Atlantic Side.  and the Capt thinks, one will be -- if we are obliged to keep on to Panama, The Capt says he shall have to return to Relajo for Coal, before he goes down &c as he has not enough on board. -- That would detain us about one day -- as Relajo is half a days Sail this side of San Juan &c  however! we hope for the best,

and down the coasts.  said to be hard to find the harbor unless some acquaintance here.  As we didnot intend to stop here, did not trouble us. -- at 12 n at Lat 16-21, North, Long 90-50. West -- distance last 24 hours 246 miles -- we have been close in shore most of the day, so near that could see persons on shore.  In one place saw a large Lake and Rivers, with Indians & cattle around -- Some unclear, appeared like fine land.  This was seen through a glass. -- This being the first trip of our Capt down, he was running along in shore "as he told me", to find out the lay of the land, and see how it compared with his Charts &c.  There was some 10 or 12 miles differences in places, he told me  he had his charts out all day on his table and would explain to his passengers -- some of them, he did not fancy all, that were on board, more than some of the rest of us, however! he treated them politely &c  Friday Oct 24th. -- It commenced blowing last night about 12 Oclock -- and this morning, we have a strong head wind, with a heavy sea on -- we are now, crossing the Gulph of Tehauntepec, some 280 miles acrost.  expect to be about 24 hours

himself, and all, as fast as they came, ashore were crazy to start off for the other Steamer -- this however was impossible as there was not mules enough to take a twentyeth part of the passengers acrost  and here we were, Some for one thing Some for another -- However I kept by the Agent telling him that I, must have mules first, as have Express &c -- He, being a Mexican and not use to such confusion &c The poor fellow hardly knew what he was doing -- or where.  He was -- first one would pull him -- then another -- and another and so on -- However! he found mules for my baggage, towards night had it packed and The fellow started with it --  he went out some 3 or 4 miles to where he lives for the night, and is to return for me and Mr Adams in the morning.  So we are all to remain here tonight. --  There is but two buildings here.  Those are but mere sheds -- nothing but sides and roof.  no floor to them -- can look through them most anywhere --  just at night we had a heavy shower -- it poured down -- and were it not for the Name of being indoors, we might as well have been out -- it continued raining most of the night -- finding that there was no help for us -- we had our supper here -- /this being a Hotel./  Then hired of the proprietor enough of one his wooden benches -- about eight inches

Sunday Oct 26th. -- Pleasant. -- all appear in good spirits as expect to be in at San Juan tonight or, tomorrow morning.  at 12 N -- in Lat. 12-18. North -- Long 0 --0 West, "as reported" -- 140 miles to San Juan at 12 N  Monday Oct 27th. -- Pleasant morning.  we arrived off San Juan Last Evening -- and lay here till daylight when we went in shore and Learn a Steamer would be ready for us on the Atlantic, as soon as we could get acrost &c -- Soon as the passengers heard this -- all prepared to Land as quick as possible Thinking the first on Shore would fare the best &c -- The passengers were obliged to hire boats to take them ashore -- as the company would not do it-- as there were but few small boats here, it took most of the day for them to get ashore -- I fared better However! -- Our Purser knew I have Express Matter to forward So he introduced me to Their Agent here and at the time on board, Saying you go ashore with me, and the Purser -- we started,  had all my duds with me, soon landed safe & sound -- and here commences troubles.  Each one for

/ or at his head / snuffing at them all night  I looked out for this -- in first place, and arranged with my next neighbor to place heads together, and Let the next look out for our feet &c -- I past a much more comfortable night, thasn have any idea of when laid down.  was wet some, by the water running down on side of the building where we laid. -- after breakfast -- had some trouble to find mules, to ride? -- however! we made out after a while -- and it was 8 Oclock before we started.  were obliged to wait for the fellow that took our things yesterday - he is to go most with us as a guide &c -- he returned for us, leaving our things / baggage &c / at his ranch some 4 or 5 miles out -- arrived at his ranch about 11 Am where we found our things all safe -- rested some half hour or so, then went on again -- as there was not any Road  - or beaten track for us to travel in much of the way -- were obliged to travel through thick woods, and under brush -- our guide on ahead, on foot cuting a path for us to drive through -- then as the Land is Low, Swampy, and it being the rainy season here now -- we are obliged to wade our animals through mud & mire, up to their middles, in some places -- with our feet draging through the mud &c -- after resting ourselves here a spell, we started on again, and

inches to lay on for the night.  we moved it up against the side of the building, to keep us from rolling off it -- Then with my bag? for a pillow I turned in.  or on /should have said,/  We took the bench to lay on as the water was over shoes, on the floor -- or ground -- underfoot &c -- Thei is the way we are to spend the night -- hard fare -- and a harder, bed  Those of our passengers not so fortunate as ourselves, in finding a bed -- say they could not let us, have much rest, through the night &c  Well! I, for one, donot expect much rest -- but have chosen this place, for the night -- rather than stand, or lay, in the water all night -- I looked out to get in on the back sides of the tables -- So should not be putted off in the water during the night, as our passengers are up to all kinds deviltry -- The fellow that took our baggage this Pm -- is to be back for us tomorrow morning at 8 Oclock, as he said -- and I hope he will as wish to get out of this place quick as possible, -- Tuesday Oct 28th. -- Pleasant morning -- found my bed rather hard, last night.  The benches were all filled -- as many on them as could lay -- not particular how.  They laid, as long as they laid down &c  Some had his neighbors feet by his pillow

know, it.  We saw them take some water from the stream, we had just waded through and put in this jar &c -- /it was something. /  Well! we finished our supper after a while -- and the table was again set for others, as there was several here to spend the night  how They fared, cannot say -- except -- not any better, as we heard -- about dark, it commenced raining hard, and where were we to spend the night, what a question to us, as This place Fonda Hotel was monopolised by the landlord & family -- seeing a small thatched Shed, nearby, and unoccupied, we took possession for the night -- some laying on the ground  some on boxes -- some here -- some there all, trying to find a dry place &c  and at last all was quiet. -- Wednesday, Oct 29th. -- Pleasant morning.  we find all alive Here this morning -- although many have suffered as some parts of the building we slept in was filled with large lice, especially up overhead, where most of them slept -- I took an old box to sleep on, below, and was not troubled with them -- hearing Them That was overhead, Swearing about These Lice.  first one -- Then

traveled along till 3 Pm. when we camped for the night at an old Mexican Ranch a filthy -- dirty place -- as one seldom, if ever sees -- never!  except in some such country as this I think -- as we did not bring provisions along with us, /not expecting to be so long crossing,/ were obliged to order something here -- This we found to be a regular stoping place, as out Guide told us -- a Posada -- Hotel.  we ordered our supper here and after a long while had it laid before us -- We had boiled Eggs -- Huevo's -- boiled as hard as stones -- Mexican -- black beans, Souked an hour or two Frijoles -- and a corn cake -- baked on a flat stone before the fire --With 2 or 3 starved Dogs, and full of Fleas too -- with as many Cats on each side of it -- Watching & Smelling of it, all the time it was baking -- before this could be baked however! they had to grind the Corn -- This was done by placing the corn on a flat stone -- then with a long round stone -- they rolled it till fine enough /as they thought/ to bake &c  Then for drinking -- we have Something  What!  we, did not ask -- it was boiled -- or warmed -- in an old stone jar of some kind -- and when turned out, was the same color as the jar -- perhaps! Tea -- perhaps Coffee -- and perhaps neither.  The most we

Thursday, Oct 30. -- Pleasant Morning. no sign of the Steamer yet, as have nothing to do, I mended my Coat and pants, torn on the trip acrost from San Juan -- There is several passengers stoping here intending to go up, in the Boat we came Down from San Francisco in -- Some 10 or a dozen Ladies in the company -- They will probably Leave here This afternoon, or tomorrow, -- Have showers here in the Evening. -- Friday Oct 31. -- Pleasant and very warm this Morning --The  passengers that were stoping here bound for Cal, Left this morning -- and as we had nothing Else to do, we were watching their movements &c  Much to the great annoyance of The Ladies, as most of them were dressed in dresses?. and were to ride on Gentlemens Saddles &c  "One says/ , I do wish, that those men would go away, not stand there watching us,"  we could see they were not use to such a trip as this, and assured Them, should They cross here again, They would not be so particular as now --from our description of The ride acrost &c They rather dreaded to start, however! They all left after a Long While/  we gave Them Three cheers, as They Started -- and mad up our mind, They would not be quite so particular on Their arrival at San Juan.  Should the Gentlemen look at Them Thus -- No Sign of The Steamer yet, for us --

another, and so on -- however! we made out to live through it, and find all here this morning --  after having a few more black Beans--, and some corn cake to eat for our breakfast we started on again about 8 Oclock Am.  found the traveling about the same as yesterday till within a few miles of the Lake -- where we arrived at noon. and here we are obliged to stop -- as the small Steamer that is to take us acrost the Lake -- has not arrived yet from her last trip down &c -- Our accommodations here are poor -- not a house in the place.  all are living in tents. -- and there is one or two large tents here kept as public houses for the accommodation of passengers &c  Did not engage rooms -- as are expecting the Steamer in evry moment -- /as the Agent tells us, here,/ -- These places are pretty much kept by natives here -- Some four small ones, by Americans -- but most prefer patronizing the natives -- as they appear more respectable by far -- -- than the Americans here. -- as there's not any signs of the Steamer -- we are to spend the night here -- have had one or two meals here -- and find them better than have found before since we landed here --Expect to put up at one of these Native tents, for the night.

Sunday Nov 2nd. -- Warm with showers this morning.  About 9 Am had a Shock of an Earthquake here, in fact " two or three, shocks. -- as there was not any signs of Steamer, and, as the Agent did not seem to care whether she came or not, -- the passengers here called a meeting, and voted to send a boat down the Lake in search of her &c -- chartered a Boat, and some 6 or 8 started off in pursuit of same. -- at Dark, nothing have been seen, or heard, from the Steamer, or boat that left here this Am -- Those That left in the boat, this Am -- expected to keep right on to the Atlantic, if they did not see the Steamer &c  So we are to spend another night here, have my hammock engaged. -- Monday Nov 3rd. -- Showers again this morning.  as theres no signs of the Steamer This morning, The Agent has concluded to charter a Schooner here, to taker the passengers down -- and while we were going to board the Steamer hove in sight, and we waited for her.  She finally arrived safe -- had been detained by going over the Falls, at the Rapids "so called" -- by some mismanagement &c.  Several times were lost, altho no damage done to the Boat.  They were several days getting her back again -- just at night we went on board of her and Started for Rivas, some 8 or 10 miles further up the Lake, where most of our passengers are

Saturday Nov 1st. -- Rains This morning Some Showers!! -- also had Showers through the night -- This has been an unpleasant day, raining most of the time -- and as could not find anything for amusement here, /being obliged to Keep in the tents for shelter, / found it to be a long, and tedious day -- all could find to amuse ourselves, was in watching The Natives, about here  This! as have said before, is a new route, passengers, having crossed here but once, or twice, before and in This place Virgin Bay, so called" on the Lake "Nicaragua."  The proposed landing place for The Lake Steamer for the transit of passengers & freight to, and from, Ocean to Ocean,/ is but one building, and That, a small one story, brick, Store House, belonging to the Co and used for the storage of baggage & freight -- This, is the only building here -- The Agent for the Co and his wife, lives in one corner of this building partitioned off -- he would not, let any of the passengers, sleep in this building nights &c so of course we were obliged , if possible, to find shelter under some of the Natives Tents here, and they charged us fifty cents, a night, for the privilege, and we could lay on the ground, or stand up all night, as we chose -- I lay upon the ground one & two nights, found it so wet, I began to grow stiff & lame, and finding that the Landlord had one or two hammocks, I engaged one of them of him paying, one dollar, a night, no advance, and Thout myself fortunate then ever -- and as The Steamer has not made its appearance yet, have it engaged for tonight

Tuesday Nov 4h. -- Showers this morning -- we lay here at Rivas all night, as the passengers did not come on board and this being a small Steamer, without sleeping accommodations atall "except for the hands", the passengers spent the night as best they could -- some laying on the deck, some on the baggage, some in one place, some in another -- I planted myself on my Valise about midships, on the Starbord Side, in the companionway, and leaning back against the Saloon, as soon as I came on board, and I intend to stick here till I find a better place -- I doubt however! of finding a better place on board This Boat  She is called The Director, and is about 15 or 20 tons burden, should judge.  might have possibly been 50 -- She is a miserable thing -- we can find to eat on board is dry bread. -- it was 4 Oclock Pm, before the passengers were all on board from Rivas -- we then left it and went down to Virgin Bay, where we stoped a few moments, and finally left at 6 Pm for the Atlantic Shores --The Steamer so crouded almost impossible to move about on board -- This however! is no inconvenience to me, /so far as moving about myself,/ as I have been siting on my valise ever since I came on board, Should I leave it, doubtful of my ever seeing it again -- several have been lost already -- So I intend to hold on to mine -- and my seat to have. --

Stoping, that being an old town with better accommodations &c -- we were obliged to get on board, the best way we could, the Steamer, laying a long distance from shore -- were put on board in Dugout Canoes "so called" paddled along Indian fashion, by the Natives. -- the wind was blowing very fresh at the time we went on board, and I expected evry moment we should roll over, had they have taken more on board the canoe I was in, /as they wanted to,/ I fear we should not have reached the Steamer safe -- The canoe was only about 10 feet long, and 1 1/2 foot wide, and three persons in it -- They, /the Natives/, wanted to take in 2 or 3 more -- but I told them no -- you take me out and I will pay the same as if all went &c, -- they at first hesitated, but findind me in Earnest, finally consented, and after a long while, landed me safe on board, and right glad was I to get out of the little thing she rolled so.  were obliged to sit flat upon the bottom, in the water all the time to prevent her going over  however! I preferred this way of getting on board, to that of being tumbled in with some 10 or a dozen others in a little larger canoe, "as the most of them went."  one of these larger ones was upset before she got 200 feet from shore, and all had a complete dunking -- baggage and all  after all had got on board, we started for Rivas for the other passengers about Dark and thankfull were we all to get away from this place Virgin Bay --

far has not been very pleasant on the River  Lands have been low for the most part since we left the Lake, till within a few miles of The Rapids, or falls.  Here the land is higher covered with woods, beautiful foliage.  The River full of snags and Alligators, below the falls, /in particular. --  Thursday Nov 6h. -- A Splendid morning, and we find ourselves at Grey-town, this morning, having arrived here about half past 11. last night.  after a pleasant, and quick passage -- last evening we past a new Steamer bound up the River, and it intended to run on The Lake, in place of the old Director. -- She was built in New York, and was towed out here by The Daniel Webster, on her last trip out, is called The Central America.  owned by the Com Vanderbuilt.  He was on board of her and hailed the Capn of our Boat, giving him orders &c -- we left the Boat about daylight for the Agent's Office here, to change tickets and see what time we could go on board of the Daniel Webster /as we were to go in her,/, were obliged to wait a Long while, for the Purser to come ashore from the D W before we could change tickets -- so we went and took breakfast, and a look about the place but soon returned to office to secure tickets and find out where to go on board &c,  have our tickets changed, and was told we could go on

Wednesday, Nov 5th. -- A Splendid morning.  all hands are Drunk or asleep, towards morning and the Steamer lay rolling in the trough of the sea Engine Stoped -- roused up after a while and started on again and arrived at San Carlos, an old Spanish Fort at the mouth of the San Juan River, and on The entrance of The Lake.  There, we are obliged to stop for permission to pass, altho should half a dozen yankees attempt it in a common sized sail Boat, without asking permission &c -- Think They could not have stoped Them -- although a most Splendid Situation, high land, beautiful scenery &c about here -- Still, like all other Mexican Forts, forsaken looking places, evry thing going to decay -- This is 60 miles from Virgin Bay, and we arrived here about 7 Am. where we waited an hour or so, and left again at 8. on our way down the San Juan River, and arrived at The Rapids, some 40. miles away from Sn Carlos about 1 Pm, where we took dinner.  Here, we changed Boats, have to walk around the Rapids, to go on board.  Am thankfull to get out of that old tub, The, Director. -- we went on board the Steamer John M. Clayton, and soon left for Grey Town, on the Atlantic coast -- This is a fine large Stern-Wheel Boat, flat bottom -- with good accommodations, for a boat of her size. -- and we expect to be on board all night, as it is some 100 miles down the River to Grey-town -- The scenery Thus

Sunday Nov 9h. -- A Strong head wind again today, with a heavy Sea on, Very Heavy.  Had all our yards, & spars, sent down topmasts, & all.  and we are jumping and pitching into it here now, anything but pleasant.  Some rain through the day.  Monday Nov 10h. -- Strong head wind again today, with a heavy sea, and Sprinkles some.  The passengers find it rather uncomfortable on board So rough -- The Capn finds he is geting short of coal -- as well as water and provisions too.  He would not stop at Havana of Them as he hopes to make a short passage, as he said -- however! These strong head winds, have been against him, and I think he is now sorry he did not stop at Havana -- Should these winds continue, we shall fare hard, and in fact! shall be obliged to put back for coal &c -- Some of the passengers blame him very much for starting atall, with so small supply of Coal, and provisions on board -- what we have had of fresh provisions, was all put on board in New York, before She Left there, had been on board ever since, not any of it is fit to eat, So old,  however! we must make the best of it now, and hope, for favorable winds & weather, the rest of the voyage --

board at, 3 Oclock, this Pm, so we left and took another look about the  place --  This is a beautiful place, the Land where the Town is situated, is a low level plain -- inhabitants mostly English, and the English have a Fort here  The stores are for the most part Kept by the English too -- it being very warm here today I made the purchase of a Thin coat at one of the stores /real English cut,/  There are some fine buildings here  especially those owned by the English government and residents but a small place 'however'. -- after Dinner, we went down and engaged a boat and went on board of the Steamer, and was on our way at 8 1/2 Pm for New York.  Friday Nov 7h. -- Some fine rain this morning, with a strong head wind.  Many of them seasick, myself among the rest, not so but am on Deck "however" -- Lost my Panama hat, while Leaning over the Sea rail today seasick. -- we made Cape Antonio Light about 9. Pm, with a strong head wind stilll blowing. -- Saturday Nov 8h. -- Strong head wind, and a heavy sea on -- in Sight of Cuba most of the day.  Have some of the fore & aft, Sail, set a few moments toady, but not long.  Wind to much ahead for them to be of use. --

Wednesday Nov 12h. -- Strong head wind, & Sea, again today.  donot make but little headway -- however! Evrything safe so far.  fine rain during the day -- / it appears from my journal, That This is the day The 12h, The meeting was called, and we putaway for Charleston &c -- altho talked over yesterday, and finally concluded to wait till today, and see if the wind & weather would not be more favorable, and as we should be nearer Charleston too, by today, should nothing happen &c  This mistake was in copying, from my journal -- Thursday Nov 13h. -- Wind has died away some, This morning, but still, a heavy Sea on.  Wind changed some in the Am. and the sun came out.  Has the appearance of clearing up, and we have a fair wind This Pm, So The Capn has had all yards & spars, run up, and all sails set this Pm and the passengers are rejoicing in This change and hope it might continue The rest of the voyage, or till we arrive at Charleston, where many, no doubt, will leave the Vessel.  I intend to, for one.  /Should we arrive there safe,/ and go on from there, by Land to NY. many others will do the same, I am, told, while all, for the Southern States, will of course Stop at Charleston -- and were very anxious we should put in there. --

Tuesday Nov 11h. -- Strong head winds yet, and an awfull Sea on, we make but little headway, and are using up our coal, fast -- our fresh water gave out a day or two since, and all we have had to use since was what had been made by the Engines, "from Exhaust Steam and the minute our coal gives out, of course! our Supply of fresh water, is stoped at once. -- finding out our situation, the passengers called a meeting -- a committee was chosen to wait upon The Capn and inform him of the doings of the meeting &c and request him to put in to the nearest port, for Coal & Provisions, -- and should he refuse to do so, when requested, the passengers were determined to take the command Themselves, by placing one of their number in command / an old Sea Capn,/ and put away for Charleston -- The committee attend to Their duties, and returned with the Capn.  He stated our conditions &c -- and said he was perfectly willing to put away for Charleston, and thought, our case might possibly last, till we arrived There -- altho Thought it doubtful &c -- however! he consented to run for Charleston, and the meeting dissolved -- and the Capn put away for Charleston -- "I say putaway, for Charleston &c" -- our course was not changed much -- not so, but that The wind, was still ahead, and, was increasing too, at This time, with a tremendous Sea on -- however!we are doing as well as can be expected at such times, I suppose -- Some fine rain during the day --

Saturday Nov 15h. -- It commenced blowing Last night about 12 Oclock, and This morning, it blows a perfect Gale, and we are going right before it, / a direct course however! for us,/  we are under close reef, foretopsail, flying, -- past Several vessels laying to -- as we were crossing the Gulf Stream.  The Ship being so light, with such a tremendous  Sea on too, could not make her mind her helm.  a heavy Sea Struck her on her Larbord quarter, carrying away a part of her Wheelhouse and causing her to broach-to and she lay in the trough of the Sea at the Mercy of The Winds & Waves.  I stood on the Hurricane Deck at the time holding on to a large iron stay, Which saved me from rolling down into the Lee Scuppers, as others did.  When the Sea struck her, and she broached too -- had it not have been for some old Sea Capts That were on board at the time, and sprung to the wheel taking charge of that -- I doubt of our having got out of this perilous situation, so quick as we did.  as the Capn of the Steamer appeared frightened at the time, -- as the Sea struck us, he The Capn," was standing just behind me, and was thrown against the Leerail, he was soon up again, but not, till The others Capts. had the wheel -- it appears this is the first voyage our Capn has ever had commend of a ship,

Friday, Nov 14h. -- Pleasant -- have had a fair wind the Last 24. hours, and all sail set -- altho not made but 254 miles, the Last 24 hours -- The Capn finding it so pleasant today, called a meeting of the passengers, to see if they were willing  he should now Stand direct for New York -- There being so many Western Men, on board, and as They all, wanted to go to New York, They carried the Day.  The Capn no doubt told them a good story, as he did not want to go into Charleston, and made Them Think it would be fair weather all the rest of the way &c.  He also stated before the meeting -- That he had been below and examined The Coalbins, and found he had coal enough to last him into N York, /provided, he had as fair wind, as now, nad pleasant weather , all the way,/  he also stated he had two barrels, of hardbread and 1 barrel, of salt beef, and some beans on board, and if we were willing to put up with this -- he thought he could possibly reach New York -- as said before -- This, satisfied the Western Men, Greenones -- and So he steamed for New York direct. -- The Southerners, as well as some of the others, were awfull mad, to think the Capn could run such risks, and threatened to prosecute him, on their arrival at, N. York, for such treatment on board.  The want of provisions -- Water, &c  However! he was bound to go, and go he did, or at least! starting for it --

Thankful were we for This Even, if our provisions, are, all gone -- however! about dark, we had a little hard bread, and a few Sardines, placed upon the tables, and all the passengers, Steerage and all, were asked in to partake &c -- not hardly enough for a taste round, however! we are Thankful for This.  had out Capn have known Known Enough, we Should not have been on quite so short allowance, now -- neither of Provisions -- or Coal. --  however! with good luck, we hope to be in to New York in the course of 48 hours from This. -- Sunday, Nov 16h. -- A Pleasant Morning, with light head wind, just right to make the furnaces draw well, and we are going along very well now -- not provisions enough on board to set the tables, so each passenger picks up what he can find in the pantry &c -- We find the Steamer did not Sustain further damage, Than That She met with, When the Sea struck her, and as She lay in the trough of the Sea yesterday Am -- This Sea struck her nearly midships, carrying away The Water Closets on the, Port Side, and about one half of The Wheelhouse -- with some 6 or 8 barrels of grease, belonging to the Cook. -- at the time the sea struck us there was a fellow in one of the closets, and he saved himself by clinging to the wreck. --

and we found that he was not equal to the emergency / or at least! we thought so / all he appeared to think of, the whole passage, was, to make a quick passage -- once more safe before the wind again, we were all ordered below, in the after cabin and were stowed in there, as thick as could stand. -- This was done in order to get all the heft - as near the her hold & stem, as possible, in order to make her mind, her helm &c -- and of course we were willing under these circumstances, to go below for our own safety &c -- the Ship was so light now.  She was tossed about, like an eggshell on the water, but so long as they can keep her before the wind, and mind her helm, we hope, to go safe -- as we lay there in the trough of the Sea, rolling about evrything in the storeroom, below broke loose and were pitching about at a great rate, our barrel of beef, the Capn. told about as well as the, beans, and hard bread, have all broken loose, and have full possession of this part of the Ship.  Yes! and more even.  as the bulkhead had been carried away, all was going from one Side of the Ship to the other, forward & back, over & under, one complete mess, all mixed up together.  as the last meal to be served up on board for the Entire Ship's company.  This state of things was kept up till about 3 Pm, when we had crossed the Gulf Stream, once past the Cape / Hatteras /  When the wind died away, and we came into smoother waters, and

Monday Nov 17h. -- Fine rain, this morning.  Have an early breakfast, and left for the Cars at 7 1/2 Am, where I found a fellow passenger a Mr Flint, that was also going on to Boston This morning.  he did not leave the Steamer till This morning -- and then was obliged to leave without his Baggage could not even get a pair of boots, to put on, So came to the Cars, with Thin Slippers on, and same dress, he wore on Shipboard.  we were the only ones, that came in This train, That is " from the Steamers passengers &c -- as we came along, see some snow had fallen lately, and there was ice in the streams -- being rather suspicious looking fellows, I suppose! -- many inquiries were made of us, as to where we were from &c -- no doubt however! all mistrusted, where we were from. -- Soon as it was known, we were from California, all have some questions to ask and we have enough to keep us busy the most of the day, answering questions &c -- however! we arrived Safe in Boston st 5 Pm, where I saw Geo Heyward, and from him, Learned all was well at home -- This was good news to me -- Mr H took me to Henrys Store, and from there we came home together, taking them rather by surprise -- Happy However" to meet all once more in Health at Home. --

we made Land, about 3 Pm, -- and Sandy Hook Light about 7 Pm, and happy were all, to see this -- we arrived at Staten Island at 9 -- Where we were oblige to wait for the health officer to board us, before going up to the City -- We notified them of our comeing, by a gun, or two, some 15 minutes before we arrived in quarantine -- a Custom house officer also boarded us here, and will stop on board -- we were detained here about 20 minutes -- and then started again for the City -- all is now confusion on board, as the passengers are preparing to go ashore if the officer, will allow them to   he tells me, he cannot, allow any baggage to be taken ashore tonight.  finding I have Express Matter for Adams & Co --he then told me, if I would not let others know it, and would watch my chance &c. could go.  I immediately  had my things on Deck. / Express Matter, and what little baggage I have too, a Small Valise, only./ am ready for a spring the moment we touched the wharf, which was about 10 Oclock Pm,  and the moment She came hear enough, I jumped, and was the first up in town, and I think the only one, that could get their baggage on shore tonight -- delivering the Express bag to Adams & Co office,  and then went to the Howard Hotel, on Broadway" where I put up for the night, giving orders to be called for in the morning for the first train of Cars, for Boston. --

From a Journal, Rept on my Second Trip to California, Monday April 3d 1854. -- We Left Boston at 5 Oclock, This Pm, for California, the 2d time, -- via the Fall River route to New York. -- Our company consisted of Mr Geo Wheeler, Mr Winslow P. Bent -- and myself. -- / Mr Wheeler accompanies us as far as New York, only. / -- have a pleasant passage, saw several on board the Boat I was acquainted with, among them Mr Cyrus Alger, of South Boston. -- We arrived at the wharf in N York, at 7 Oclock Am on Tuesday morning The 4h and went direct to the St Nicholas Hotel, where we all engaged Rooms. -- after breakfast, I called on Edward Greene, & Sisters, and in the Pm -- Winslow & I, went to the Crystal Palace -- in the Eve Winslow & Geo Wheeler went out somewhere -- I wrote a line home and retired early -- This has been a pleasant day -- but cool and dusty. --

fine sail down the harbor. -- two other Boats Started about the same time / just after / with passengers bound for California too.  The Stmrs North Star -- and Northern Light, two opposition boats, -- ours being the regular Mail Boat -- past Sandy Hook, before sundown, the North Star came along side and past up on the Port side about Sundown, but the Northern Light is some 6 or 8 miles astern of us at dark.  about this time, many began to think, they would turn in, as it began to grow some rough and the motion not so agreeable as it might be, Winslow & I among the rest. -- Thursday April 6h. -- Pleasant morning, but cool.  had a fine run last night.  The other Boats not to be seen this morning -- our course about South, Wind South West, -- among the passengers in board of our boat, is Capn Watkins, and Some of his officers, of the ill fated Steamer San Francisco, also some of the Troops that were aboard her at the time She was wrecked &c.  Capn Watkins, has his wife with him also. -- our room mate is a Mr Steams, from Somerville, Mass, a Gentlm, of whom have heard the young Ladies in Dorchester,  speak of -- find him to be good

Wednesday, April 5h. -- Pleasant morning.  as I was expecting a package from Boston, by Express, I went down to Adams & Co before breakfast. -- They were not open.  So went back again to Hotel. -- and then went down again in the course of an hour or so. -- after waiting an hour, or more, I recd the package, then returned, and had my breakfast   after breakfast, packed things in trunk and went down to the Steamer, ' The Illinois" with our baggage all ready for the voyage. -- packed our things, what we could" in our State Room.  Then -- as the Steamer was not ready to sail, Winslow & I went up in town a short distance, and bought a few private Stores.  I, returned to the Boat, but Winslow, went up in town to meet Geo Wheeler, -- the soon returned to Boat -- and we then Examined Said Stores -- it now being about time to start all was confusion, on board.  The Wharf -- as well as the boat, was crouded with people passengers & their friends. -- as the bell rung for the last time, notifying all, that were not, going to go on shore &c -- We could see tears, start from many -- many eyes -- and such parting scenes, one seldom, if ever, sees -- Wdward Greene & Geo Wheeler, left, with the others -- and we were soon under way.  cast off from the wharf about half past 2. Pm.  It being very pleasant, we had a

Saturday April 8h. -- Pleasant -- wind S E.  our course about South -- fore & main Spencer Set -- most of the passengers on Deck till about 4 Pm. When the wind commenced blowing, and the Sea to rise --So that most were obliged to go below.  at 12 N -- had made 214 miles in the Last 24 hours --wind begins to increase in the Evening, and the prospects are a rough night -- Oh! -- who would nt take a Sea voyage? -- Sunday April 9h. -- Cloudy -- we had a strong S E wind all night, and still continues this Am. -- but very few at tables this morning.  These heavy Seas, are not in the least favorable  towards giving a person a good appetite for the meals &c -- Neither Winslow nor I went down to the tables.  Had a cup of tea however! just enough to keep our side good "over the rail." -- have had a heavy Sea all day, but few passengers on deck.  However! I have managed to keep on deck most of the time as I feel better when I can have good pure air to breathe -- Sea some smoother in the Evening and Some of our Lady passengers were on deck Singing Sacred, and other music -- were

company, and a Gentleman. -- at 12 N. have mad in the 21.hours out from New York, 106 miles, -- a long heavy swell on, this Pm.  Not many inclined to move about much today, especially The Ladies  find we have quite a number of them, on board, Some of them however! donot show to a very good advantage today, / Sea sick, / They lay around rather loose today -- but we wont laught too soon, as our turn may come next. -- Friday April 7h. -- Pleasant, but a strong head wind S.W. with a heavy sea on, and most of the passengers sea sick -- all rather quiet today -- as I expected yesterday, our turn came today, and we were to be seen, occasionally hanging on the Lee rail. -- at 12. N , have made 105 miles in the Last 24. hours, -- Sea some smoother in the Eve, and some few Ladies were on Deck   fine moonlight night, all are glad to get on Deck for fresh air -- very unpleasant below in cabins, so many sea sick there. --

Wednesday April 12h. -- Pleasant, and very warm this morning.  We made the Island of Jamaica, about Sunrise, and at 8 Oclock Am. took on board two black fellows, as Pilots, and went in to Kingston, for Coal.  we arrived at The Wharf here about 12. N -- where we found the Steamer Northern Light, that sailed from N York the Same day we did.  She put in for Coal too -- This City, Kingston, is situated on low land, and in, some 3 miles from the open Sea.  The English have a fort, and a Naval Depot, at the entrance of this harbor,  Here, we were oblige to stop, and were boarded by the Health, & Custom house officers, were detained some hours by them before allowed to go up to the City. -- as we neared the wh[arf] we were surrounded by the blacks, who came swimming out alongside, and asking for money -- "Massa, please give me a dime," was the cry from all, and the passengers on board amused themselves by throwing five & ten cent pieces, overboard to see them dive for them.  Soon as a piece was thrown over, all that was near, would start and dive for it -- and the one that got it was the best fellow -- or person, I should have said, as there was both Male & Female -- When one of them got a piece, they would put it in their mouth, and watch their next chance -- some would

one to judge from Their Looks, would not think they felt much like singing. -- / if So ! one would Say Their countenances bespoke Sacred Music, altogether, -- evry few moments you would see some of them creep off Slyly and hurry for the side of the Ship.  Only Seasick, thats all!! -- at 12 N had made 213 miles, the Last 24. hours. -- Monday April 10h. -- Pleasant-- wind about South -- our course about S.S.West.  The Sea is much smoother today, and quite warm.  I put on a Thin Coat   we made Land about 1 Pm on our Starbord bow.  Watlings Island, "so called".  I was on Deck till 11 Oclock Pm -- have a game of Euchre in the Eve -- at 12N have made 195 miles the Last 24 hours -- Tuesday April 11h. -- Pleasant, and very warm today -- had a fine Smooth Sea the Last 24 hours -- and not a breath of air this Am -- not a ripple even, on the water -- came in sight of Cuba about 10 Am -- and was in sight of it most of the day -- the passengers appear to enjoy themselves today it is so pleasant -- at 12.N have made 245 miles.  the Last 24 hours. --

and keep up a terrible noise -- Singing -- they call it".  but such as one would not wish to hear more than once. -- Soon as they commenced coaling it was so dirty on board -- coal dust".  The passengers began to go on shore --and were glad to improve thiss opportunity, after being on board Ship a week or so -- The population here is mostly Blacks, and they are the most Lazy -- insolent -- and filthy set of beings -- I ever saw -- the male portion in particular.   They live, as we were told here, by stealing almost impossible to get one to work -- and this has been the case, / as we were told here by some of the English residents / Ever since their Emancipation -- They tell us it is not of any use for a person living near town, to attempt to raise anything -- as these Blacks will steal so -- This is the way they get their living -- stealing fruit &c -- and selling the same to passengers, and others, that arrive here by Steamers, and other vessels.  When a Steamer arrives here, this, is, a great time for these blacks -- they calculate to get money out of the passengers & others, to last them till another comes in -- fruits of all kinds, Tropical, were exposed for sale at evry corner of the streets -- and in fact -- at almost Evry step, in the Street -- by these miserable beings, blacks! miserable, I say. --

have their mouths nearly full -- / some of the best swimmer, / -- as they dive for these pieces we could see them for a long distance under water scrabling for the piece.  We could see them push and pull one another while under water, and sometimes would use their fists, a regular set-to, at fisticuffs -- They come so near, sometimes when the wheels are in motion, they are obliged to dive to get out of the way,  -- and sometimes will pass under the vessel and come up on the other side. -- This quite a large, and I should Say safe harbor, in a storm -- although the Land being so low about here a vessel may be some exposed to heavy winds here, but then not much danger of a heavy sea, here so far in -- and so crooked a channel up to the Town &c -- Soon as we have made fast, the work of Coaling commenced -- and this is done by the blacks, "females" coming on board in twos of about 75, or 100, pounds each, on the heads of these blacks -- each one takes her tub upon her head and starts on a dog trot for the vessel.  As they arrive opposite the coalhole, each throws their tub full in, without stoping and pass out another way -- and in this way they keep a continual stream of coal pouring in, till full -- all the time these blacks are at work, they appear very cheerfull

Them -- we finished coaling about 11 Pm a most splendid moonlight Evening, and most of the passengers are on Deck -- I was below part of the Eve writing letters to mail on our arrival at Aspinwall home!  about 12 at night -- we got under way again, and past slowly down the harbor on our way out to the Sea again, were obliged to go slow on account of so crooked and narrow a Channel -- before starting from the Wharf our pilots hung a lantern on one of the buoys, down the harbor, so as not mistake them, as we came down -- We past the Fort about 1/2 past 12 -- Where we fired a salute as we passed / as is customary /, and on we went, -- discharging our pilots about 1, when clear of all land, and on we went again. -- I remained on deck till our pilots Left -- and we were fairly out to Sea once more -- and then retired. -- Thursday April 13h. -- Pleasant, but some rough this Am.  many of our passengers are seasick again today -- we took on board some 6 or 8 more passengers at Kingston one a black fellow, he was so frightened by the Steerage passengers -- telling him they would sell him for a Slave, on our arrival at Aspinwall. --

as they are, The most filthy race of beings I ever saw -- worse than the brute creation, by far -- if such, are the fruits of Emcipation, give me, Slavery -- The Blacks, in the Island of Cuba, are  as much superior to these here -- in Evry respect -- both Morally,  and Socially as one can well imagine -- / I refer to the Slaves in Cuba./ -- The Gentlemen passengers all went on shore first and went up in town to see if worth a while to invite the Ladies to go on Shore -- and as They, The Ladies wished to arranged their toilet &c / which by the way / were one to judge from observation on board for some days past) would Say/, They have been sadly neglected -- especially by the Lady passengers -- / poor Things, / -- happy to think we had none under our charge during the passage so far,   The Gentlemen That had Ladies with Them, or under their charge, returned to Steamer for Them, and Lined up in town, at a Hotel, so called here" -- after dinner Winslow and I called in at several of the stores here to see what they had for sale &c -- we each bought a Panama Hat, and I went into a Barbers, and had my hair cut--. Stores are kept by English all pounds -- Shilling & pence, with

however! cast a gloom over the Ships company for a Short time -- Soon forgotten tho -- we also have some 5 or 6 fellows That secreted Themselves away on board as we lay at Kingston -- White fellows -- Some were Sailors, from the English Service -- run away's -- and one or two Natives, I think.  Soon as they were found, they were placed in Irons below, for about One Day, Then brought on Deck, and set at work Scrubbing Decks, and were kept at this all the time during the rest of the passage. -- One of them, was very seasick and tried to beg off, from work, but No!  work he must.  The poor fellow was so sick, he was obliged to run every few moments for the Side of the Ship -- as is natural to all in case of Seasickness, and have Strength Enough left to reach there. -- he worked it off however! but from appearances, was sory he came on board, I thought. -- at 12 N. 11 hours out from K--- we were 100 miles out from Kingston -- our course today about South -- The wind so as to have some sail set -- in the Pm and Evening, rained some. -- Friday April 14h. -- Pleasant -- Warm and Sultry -- our course today, little west of South, wind East,

That he watched an opportunity and jumped overboard -- it was by mere accident that anyone saw him as he jumped -- and in fact it was a long time before could find out, who it was --Soon as the cry of Man Overboard was given, The Engines were stoped, and a Boat Lowd?, -- but it was with the greatest difficulty She was Mand as there was such a Sea on at the time -- all feared she would swamp alongside -- however! The succeeded after a while, and put back in direction, near as possible, to where he jumped -- and at the same time The Steamer backed -- nothing could be seen of him but his hat.  Soon after the boat left the side of the Ship, however! I saw him come up a long distance astern, he gave his head a Shake and immediately disappeared again, he went down so quick Think a Shark, or something caught him, as he appeared to be drawn down feet first -- This was the last That was ever Seen of him -- There was some 4 or 5 of us That Saw him come up -- and then go down as have stated -- The Boat returned, and with great difficulty and danger, came along side again -- after some time was able to catch ropes from the Ship, -- and, with the assistance of all on board, that could lend a helping hand, they were soon Safely on board again, and the Steamer on her way once more. the Cars were to start for Panama. -- here we were told the Cars would not go till next morning -- This we did not like However! as we could not help ourselves -- we have to make the best of it. -- so we engaged Rooms, rather beds, all in one room, at the United States Hotel, / as they call it here /,  Here we were obliged to pay one day, in advance, to secure our beds &c -- so we paid, and had our Room Shown us, Where we put our Things, and then cleaned up a little -- afterwards some of our party went out to see if the Rail Road Co would not dispatch a special train with our passengers. -- They finally decided to do so. -- so we collected our Things Together again, and told the Landlord, how it was -- and he paid us back our money -- we then left for the Cars, Where we sat till about 1 Pm before we started -- we have not much time to see the place here, neither did it require much time to see all there was here to be seen -- There are but few buildings here, being quite a new place -- The Land is very low & wet, all a swamp -- buildings Set on Stilts, / most of them, / -- and were I to select a place Where Should Think Sickness, or Diseases of all kinds, might abound -- it would be This place -- Stagnant water, covers most of the place here -- notwithstanding the Town is so near the

at 12 N -- have made 245 miles the last 24. hours -- and at the same time were 204 miles from Aspinwall. -- This last news, The passengers were happy to hear, as we have began to get tired of being on board of Ship. -- in the Pm some of the passengers began to pack Their Things away, so as to be ready to go on Shore as soon as the Steamer arrived at the Wharf in Aspinwall -- Should nothing happen we expect to arrive there, some time tomorrow.  it has been very warm -- and sultry all day.  Saturday April 15h. -- Pleasant and very warm -- We expect to arrive at Aspinwall, some time This Am, So I finished letters that commenced at Kingston, We mail out letters for home, on board This Steamer, before Landing, as they will be taken to New York by her, on her return trip &c --our passengers are all very busy packing their trunks, and dressing Themselves for the trip across the Isthmus -- I was so buisy among the rest, I hardly saw the harbor, as we came up. -- not much of a harbor to be seen however! as it lays all open to the Sea. -- We arrived at Aspinwall about 10 Am, -- have our baggage checked for transit acrost, and left the Steamer for the Depot, to see when

warm & dusty -- We arrived at Obispo about Sundown, where we are to Spend the night.  This Town is 30 miles from Aspinwall -- and from here-- we are to go on mules to Panama. -- as we intend to stop here tonight we engaged lodgings at Old Jos "as he is called", a Black fellow -- and is known by all that has ever crossed here, he came here to the Isthmus, and opened an Eating House, "or Hotel as he calls it" when the California Excitement first commenced and has been here ever since, and I am told he is worth some 1-- or 300,000 dollars, as the Rail Road is finished, he moves along and builds a shanty to accommodate passengers as they cross back & forth -- There are several other's there beside him, that accommodate passengers for / what they can get, / but Old Jo get the most of them -- he is a fine clever old fellow good natured as can be, all like him __ as his place is small he is obliged to set his tables several times to accommodate all his customers &c -- and should one wish to enjoy a meal here, he must not pay his Kitchen or cook room a visit before Eating -- as I was waiting to get a chance to get something to eat, I took a walk round his place and see his cooks preparing something for Supper -- the Negros catch

Sea Shore, the Land near high water mark being some 2 or 3 feet higher, -- There's no chance to drain the water off &c   And as said before it seems to me a fit place for almost any and all kinds of Epidemics -- not a drop of water in the whole place fit for a White Man, to drink / or a Dumb beast even, /  we found it very hot siting in the Cars, waiting for them to start, -- and we dare not leave them, for fear they would start off without us. -- Some of the passengers were thoughtful enough to fill a bottle with water  before leaving the Steamer, thinking might not find any on shore fit for drinking -- Such of us who did not bring water from the Steamer -- were obliged to drink wine they bought here on shore, paying 50 cents, a bottle for it and if you asked for a glass of water, you had to pay 10 cents a glass for it -- / and this too, such as was taken from the swamp here, / I concluded it would be a rather poor place to form a Temperance Society.  Not a temperance man -- / or woman / in the whole company -- most every one had a bottle by them. -- On out way to Obispo the Town where the Cars Stop, and as far as the Rail Road is finished -- we found it very hot & oppressive -- Exceedingly so -- and most of our passengers found a bottle full, lasted but a short time, so

Sunday April 16h. -- All hands were called at 3 Oclock This morning, "I say called". but not awoke by calling as there had been such an awful noise all night we could not sleep. -- one would think, all from The Infernal Regions had been let loose and congregated here, for our special benefit.  Some of them would ride their mules into the house and drive up to the bar, for a drink, being too drunk to get there, and back again, any other way -- and in fact they kept on their mules most of the night, for the very purpose of being able to get back, & forth, from one bar, to the other.  just so long as there was life enough in them, to hold on, and strength enough to raise a glass to their lips &c -- We were called early -- that we might get an early start --had our breakfast at 4, and prepared for a start -- our party started about 1/2 past 4. Am from this place Obispo.  many however! had started before this, and some few went on last Eve / altho not considered safe to travel here nights / -- it was a most splendid morning, and the Moon, some 3 or 4 hours high when we started, and not a cloud to be seen.  We traveled along leisurely by ourselves Mr Stearn's -- Winslow and Myself, and arrived at the Town of Cruices, about daybreak

One a Judge TO -- who had his family with him -- finding all the Ladies roomed together -- he concluded to go round with the Bo-hoys -- and such a noise as they kept up all night, I never heard before -- neither do I wish it again. -- however! I made out to live through it -- and found all safe in the Morning. --

before we were on our way again, -- soon as it began to grow light.  The birds began to sing in the woods that surrounded us on all sides, and it was perfectly delightful -- add to this the fragrance of the Wild Flowers, that were to be seen in all directions, and you have  / what some might call / a perfect Paradise -- it was lovely -- to say the least -- as we journeyed on, we overtook some that started before we did.  While others that left after us, overtook us. -- some were hurrying through as fast as possible, while others took it leisurely -- like ourselves, as there was no occasion for hurrying through so, -- Same as yesterday we found water scarce, and what was, to be found -- hardly fit to drink -- Little however! was to be seen on the road, Except, at the little shops by the Road side, / kept by natives, / and here, we were obliged to pay a dime, a glass, / same as yesterday, / -- as the Sun got up, it began to grow warm -- and at 10. Am -- it was very hot. -- we finally arrived at Panama about 2 Pm, after one of the most tedious miles I, ever experienced --and at one time, within about 10 miles of Panama, I thought it almost impossible for me to go further the Sun was so very hot. Tuesday April 18h. -- Pleasant, and very warm again -- both boats / The Oregon & Yankee Blade / are ready to receive Their passengers.  This morning -- we are to take the regular Mail Boat, The Oregon -- after breakfast we must down to the wharf, and here took a Launch with some 20 or 30 others -- and baggage enough to load her down to the gunwale, and went on board The Steamer at about 9 Oclock, Am. -- The Steamer lay about 3 miles from the City, cannot get nearer so shallow water -- and at low tide these Launches cannot go any wheres near the wharf's -- so the passenger are obliged to wade out to, and from, them, or -- be carried by the natives on their backs, and This, The Lady passengers object to at first -- however! as they find this is the only way at such times, they are obliged to submit to it --.  To see a string of some 15 or 20 -- as at time Men & Women, being taken from, or to, a Launch in this way -- makes a comical show, and a considerable sport for the passengers -- however! as the tide was up this morning, we could get on board the Launches at the Wharf --  we were soon safe alongside of the Steamer, and finally on board all safe and here we were obliged to wait till about 1 Oclk Pm -- before all the passengers were on board. -- got under way about 1/2 past 1 -- The Yankee Blade about half an hour the Stern of us -- finding there were so many more
